reviewText:
Early Access Review

The fact that you are still seeing this game on steam is a result of three groups of people negating their responsibility.

1. The developers of course, for abandoning the game and quite literally walking off with gamers money.

2. Valve, for not removing abaondoned early access games from Steam and offering refunds to those burnt gamers.

3. Us - the gamers - for allowing Dejobaan Games LLC to continue as a company despite the first two points.

Oh and Dejobaan? Finish a game before starting on another one. Also give me (and the rest of the gamers that put faith in you in this title) my money back.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What can I say about this game. It is the first early access game on steam. A game that has been in a state of early access for 4 years and 8 months(April 1st, 2011) and no sign of ever going gold. In fact, it has been so long since it's last update that it has almost been as long since it was updated as the offical launch of early access games on steam. If Valve had taken a look at how early access worked for this game I doubt they would have ever allowed any early access games on steam. Why any game that has not been updated in over two years without being formally released is allowed to stay avalible to customers to purchase is beyond me.

Truthfully, it's not a horrible game but it is far from great. Most of my hours came from stress testing a video card. This game would cause crashes more often then any other I owned at the time. The rest came from the 2011 potato thingy for portal 2 launch. If your a fan of games that use your own music to generate levels I would recommend a bunch of others others over this one. Even Dejobann's other game AAAAaaaAAaaAAaaaaAAAA!!!!! does the concept much better and is more polished than this rendition. I just can't recommend this game to other people.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Intro:

1...2...3... Kick It is a music game modelled after Dejobaan's earlier game, Aaaaaa
date: in which the player base jumps" and avoids a series of obstacles on their way to the ground.  This iteration is only a spiritual successor
recommended: as Dejobaan has removed many of the more action-oriented elements from their formula and has instead tried to craft a new genre of relaxing music game with only two or three core gameplay mechanics instead of the many kisses
hoursPlayed: combos
voteText: landings
helpfulPercent: and tricks we saw in "Aaaaa." The concept is much simpler now: fly close to objects to earn something called "TB
votesHelpful:
and you also get something nice if that object is oriented towards the bottom of your screen. There are no landings, tricks, combos, or crowds to show off to. Because the game is STILL IN PROGRESS, I am trying to be as fair as possible. Please understand that any of the bullet points below may be changed or improved by the time you are reading this.

The Good:

* The graphics are visually interesting, but there is still room for improvement. I imagine a music game should have something more than plain black backgrounds.

* The Game is constantly updated.

* Interesting and well-developed soundtrack. I am not super into music but I thought the lyrics and beats were fun to listen to.

* The developers are some of the nicest people in the world. Drop by the Steam community forums and see for yourself: they respond to every bug, glitch, and criticism with poise and patience.

The Bad:

* Not all updates are good. For example, it used to have a nice voiceover AI in the menus, which for some reason was replaced by silence in the latest update. Silent menu screens? In a previous build, I was unable to load any actual levels due to the way the game saves music.

* The full-screen is not working at the time of this writing. It opens a window large enough to fill my screen, but there is still the familiar Windows 7 title bar at the top.

The Ugly:

* There is nothing that I can see to qualify this as a music game. Some obstacles will pulse" with the beat of the music
votesTotal: but everything else in the level seems to be pre-scripted. I can listen to Dolly Parton or speed metal while playing and get the same experience. My recommendation for the Developers would be to replace the black background with something colorful that responds to the music.\n\n* The free-falling mechanic is just not that interesting or immersive like it was in Dejobaan's first game (which was not very immersive to begin with). This feels more like a rail-shooter than a falling simulator. There is no rush of wind passing my ears
votesFunny: no way to slow or speed my descent
commentsCount:
and absolutely nothing to remind me that I am falling down instead of running sideways or flying upwards.

Conclusion:

Because the game is still in development at the time of this writing
column16: I think this review (and any others) should be read in that context. Unfortunately
column18: I never-the-less foresee "1...2...3... Kick It" as being noteworthy just for coming alphabetically in your list of games
column19: and not for the enjoyable time you spend playing it."

date: we can't please all of the people all of the time"). Valve refuse to refund despite their complicitness in promoting it during a 2011 sale.\n\nThis is a total scam and should be avoided at all costs. Dejobaan should be ashamed of themselves
recommended: if they're actually capable of feeling such."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

1... 2... 3... KICK IT! is a rhythm/skydiving game. It's AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! but the level design is set to music.

It's permanently stuck in early access, but oddly has been developed a bit over the years. It's gone through 2 or 3 major engine rewrites, but seems to be stuck in very early development anyway. Don't buy it if you expect a 'finished' game experience.

There are a few songs made for the game, which are decent.
You can hand it your music library and it'll try to generate levels based on that, but the music analyzer is buggy.

That's about all I can say about it because there's not that much to do in the game. While A Reckless Disregard for Gravity had point-collecting and levels to unlock, this game can't really do that because of how random the level design is. There's no progression and no sense of achievement because the game experience varies wildly depending on the randomness of the level generator.

The difficulty is pretty pointless because there's no death or failure state, just less points than you would have had for doing well. Also, there's no rating system or metric for how well you did, just an arbitrary number (and the devs have rewritten the scoring system a few times as well). If I get a 'high' score, I don't know if I actually did well or the song was just easier than most. Often, longer songs will net you more points by default because you get a few points per second, and longer song = more time to get points.

I just can't recommend the game because even though it seems like a decent concept, it doesn't have that much potential and it seems to be totally dead.

To be a game I'd recommend, it would need:
-an entirely different music analysis/level generator that actually makes sense for the song
-a scoring system that can tell you how well you did vs. the difficulty and length of the song
-some way to actually progress or increase difficulty over time, some way to actually fail a song
-something that actually makes you move with the rhythm, like osu! or audiosurf. Playing with full audio is no different from having the music muted because the music only affects the quantity of obstacles, not their placement or their difficulty.

And if the dev team hasn't done this in the last 4-ish years it's probably not going to happen anytime soon.

The problem is that even if this game escapes 'early access' status and fixes these issues, it doesn't seem like it could ever be as fun as AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! which still makes this a game I can't recommend. It has some potential, but when compared with other rhythm games or other arcade games, it just won't compete even as a 'finished' product. AaaaaAA only works because of the fluidity and uniqueness of the level design, and if you take that away or leave it up to a music analyzer, you remove the challenge of AaaaaAA and make it repetitive because all levels have to be (about) the same.

Ultimately, you should only buy it if you are a die-hard Dejobaan fan for completion's sake.

About 5 years ago I got this game in the Potato Sack Pack.
Since then it's always sat at the top of my library, seeing as it's sorted alphabetically.
I decided to check it out just now and noticed there was only one achievement: 'I Beat City 15'

I sat here, played through the intro level and decided to skip straight to City 15 just to save time.
After a bit of searching around, I couldn't find the level. A quick google search led me to the conclusion that the developers removed the level, but kept the achievement up. 3 years ago, the devs said they would fix it.
2016 still no fix.
10/10 devs, you got us good

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to like this game. I loved the other games Dejobaan have made in the past, and I was curious to see what they would do with Ugly Baby, so I was eager to pick it up. I didn't mind it being in early access since I had faith in their abilities to create a game (especially after Aaaaaaah), and it was one of the reasons that the Potato Sack from 2011 worked so well. There was a lot of good potential there.

It's been a few years now, and there's still nothing here but an incomplete game. In fact, it's worse; last year, I was at least able to load the game and run the few test levels (and, admittedly, had fun with them). Now the game has trouble booting up, and when I do manage to get it working, absolutely nothing works.

I'm very disappointed by this, and despite my enjoyment of their other titles, their quality is definitely taking a hit in my eyes. The lack of public accountability (or even timely updates) is especially frustrating.

In other words, unless you see an update with something along the lines of the game is finished!"
date: I would sadly say to stay away from this title."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is basically a game with such a gimmicky, boring concept, that even its developers abandoned it. The game feels much closer to some amateur's experimental project in programming than to a real, sellable product.

The gameplay itself revolves around falling through a level that's based on some techno song that plays in the background, while trying to avoid obstacles and hit little targets. Like I said, the concept gets old quickly, and you'll find little to no variety when falling through the same geometrical obstacles and trying to align yourself with the targets.

Imho, there are much better rhythm games, and even better, games that let you use your own song library, so if you're looking for something like that, I recommend you look around instead of getting this one.

Since I got this in the Potato Sack, quite a while ago, I don't feel that much ripped off but, seriously, I feel bad for whoever bought this from the store.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I played the original 'AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA', I was thinking how great would it be to combine this formula with level generation based on music tracks? When I found out, 'Ugly Baby' was exactly that, I immediately bought it, although it stated on the store page (Early Access wasn't even a concept back then) that this game was still in beta, but the full release was an automatic update, as soon as it got out. I then realized that what I had bought was a very, very early just playable version with few different levels.

By now, time has passed and Dejobaan have release several other games, but this one is still stuck in development hell. I'd love to see a full version once and I appreciate the engine migration and all the stuff that happened since the potato sack like a few additional stages, but a full version is due since a very long time ago.

When the full version is out, I'll properly review the game again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The first time I played this game it was kind of fun, but very difficult, and got old quickly, so I uninstalled. That was the last time I ever got it to work. Now after reinstalling, it's just a mess.

First off, the menu controls make no sense. When you first load it up, you get a full screen with some robot voice saying the news, with no text. I tried hitting all kinds of buttons and keys and nothing happened, then I clicked my mouse and it went to a menu. From the menu, the options are gibberish and some of them don't even do anything. Loging in as Akumi or whatever seems to start the game. From there it appears you select a level. Start the level and you hear nothing bit wind noise, but no display other than what appears to be a frame around the edges and a cursor in the middle.

I've tried playing this game multiple times over the past year or so, got 18 minutes into it trying to figure out how to even get it to do anything at all, but it's totally broken. The developer seems to have abandoned it. It's a neat concept, it might be cool if it actually worked.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI paid into the alpha of this in 2010? I think two games have come out since? Don't get me wrong. What it's slowly becoming over the years is neat and all. But it hardly gets updated. Steam Early access didn't exsist, and the game had all this promise. Meanwhile Dejobaan has been working on other games instead. It seems to me that the money from this was used to help fund games like the just released Drunken Robot Pornography. At one point 123 kick it was totally scrapped and just turned into another game. Same idea as before, but totally different mechanics. The forum seems active, and Dejobaan pretends to listen. Heck, it even says so in the Early Access Description. But the truth is, it's been at LEAST ~3 to 4 years since I paid for this, and it hasn't been updated since what, July of 2013? I dunno.. It seems to have a ton of promise if Dejobaan would actually work on it, instead of putting out games like DRP. If you buy this now, you get a very basic Alpha with a very small handful of levels. While I enjoy what's there, I just can't recommend this to anybody. I'm sorry.

Early Access Review

The freefall idea while building score and avoiding objects is actually a lot of fun. The soundtrack on top of this got me to go back and play the levels more than once.

However I would say buying this game is actually kind of a waste of time at the moment because it is INCOMPLETE!!!

If it ever gets finished and or any amazing additions get added to the game I will revisit it again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a rhythm game revolved around base jumping; It comes with some of its own quirky songs or you can play your own. It seems to be stuck in what I'd call Developer Limbo-- That, or the development for this game is agonizingly slow. While the concept is an interesting one, gameplay still has a very barebones feel to it and there are bugs to iron out still (It failed to load the song on the first level for me when I started the game for the first time.) You can still get a fair amount of gameplay out of it regardless but I'd pass this up unless you're a die-hard fan of rhythm games.

I reccomend their other game (AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!!) instead for a more finished product-- Albeit without the music element to it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So this game has had a whopping overhaul since I last played it.  Dejobaan have clearly lavished a lot of time on the interface.  The game is also totally different from the pre-alpha... Gone seem to be the crazy music-video like spirally tentacles and psychadelic backgrounds.. They've been replaced with lots of flashing and pulsing cubes.

The other major plusses for this new version are the radio voiceovers which are amusing, the music which is not too bad, and the controls which feel very fluid.  the city map" screen is enigmatic in its inscrutibility... I can seem to play any of the "levels".. so why are they linked
date: as if it's some kind of progression?  What do any of the descriptions mean?  What's the benefit of playing any one level?\n\nThe answer
hoursPlayed: is "none of it makes a blind bit of difference".   All the levels look
voteText: feel
votesHelpful: except for a few which seem to be cut-scenes.\n\nSadly
votesTotal: the game is missing any form of coherence whatsoever.  I so dearly want to love this game. I really enjoy Audiosurf
votesFunny: but that has no pretence of being a "game".. just a "ride your music" simulator.\n\nWhat does 1..2..3 need?  Well
commentsCount: it needs a single-player game for starters:  Let the player play the game using pre-determined music to begin with.  Make it nice and easy.. fun.. like it used to be.. before they added the "three strikes and your out" annoyance.  Once you're through
column16: and have cracked the game using the pre-determined scores and music
column17: open it up.. Let people play whatever.. like Audiosurf..   Add a *POINT* to the game.. you're a spy
column18: trying to scan for agents.. or you're trying to find someone.. any point to "scanning" would be good
column19: rather than just point scoring...\n\nTo be honest
column20: I couldn't be bothered with this new version.  It's a real shame because Dejobaan have clearly tried to salvage it from it's pre-alpha state.  Sadly
column21: it's missed the mark a little.   I haven't got time to put all my music through this to see what makes a "fun" level
column22: because I doubt that any of the levels are truly "fun"
column23: now that you've got the rule that "hit three things and you're dead".\n\nI have an urge to create a boring 1hr long MIDI track with a single note
column24: and AFK-ride that note from the comfort of in front of the telly
column25: returning to see I'd scored the highest score ever..  But it's just not worth it.\n\nI still can't give this a thumbs-up
column26: despite the fact it's oh-so-close to being awesome.  Sorry

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was originaly sold for full price but wasn't even completed.

After being put on hold for a few years (still being sold) the developers figure they would now start working on it again. So now the game goes from a full retail game and gets put into Early Access". I'm still not really sure how it's even legal to sell an incomplete game and have it slip past and get thrown on the Steam store to make money.

The game has gotten a complete makeover and went from a game about playing music and falling through a stage collecting a score and shooting...well...nothing
date: you see they gave you a gun to shoot stuff but because it was never finished there was nothing to shoot. The gun has since been removed and now the game is nothing more than a screen saver that plays your music.\n\nNow the whole point of the game is to fly through a stage and get as close to an object to gain a score but you need to avoid making any kind of contact with it or you get hit
recommended: but don't worry because you can't die... I'm not really sure the developers even know what they want the game to be or what they're trying to go for. Any other music driven game knows what it wants to do and it does it well
hoursPlayed: this game on the other hand doesn't and in fact if you really wanted you could load up a song and just let go of the mouse and the level will complete itself with no assistance needed.\n\nIf you want a game with absolutely no objective and no real reason to exist then this is the game for you
voteText: but if you actually want a game for your money then avoid this game at all costs."

Apparently this game is still in beta or whatever (it says Early Access on the page), which is weird to me, because that's a LONG ♥♥♥ time to be in beta or alpha or whatever. (It's been roughly 2 years now, I think)

And that may explain why I felt the way I did during the x amount of time I spent on it to get the cards. The game is fun, but it feels like it's missing something. For one thing, it needs some kind of indicator to show what unlocks the next city (unless I'm an idiot and just missed it), because I have no idea how. The first few cities unlocked after doing the prior city once, and then when I hit city 5, the next one didn't unlock, and I was like huh?". After doing it 2 more times
recommended: but I have no idea what I did differently.\n\nThen
hoursPlayed: the core of the gameplay itself feels like it's just lacking something in general. As far as I could tell

helpfulPercent: avoiding the blocks. You use your mouse to move

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is reminicent of AaAaAA!!! - A Reckless Disregard for Gravity. The mechanics are almost identical except there's no landing needing to be done at the end of a level. The levels can be generated based on any MP3 you have in your collection, so you can basically fly through your music. The first few levels were pretty slow going and merely ok. For a fluke I tried out one of the last levels (since they're all unlocked at the beginning) and it was much faster and more interesting. I actually had to deal with some quick thinking that gets you into a sort of zone.

Overall I would say it's an ok casual game, but more of something mindless to do than a game to really engage in. I'll put it into my casual bin, but I probably won't play it very often.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a great game if you're looking for something that you can with out having to set aside large chunks of time to play it. I feel like I've had this game for almost as long as its been of on steam and I still love starting it up and playing when ever I need to kill time between classes and can't play something more involved. That being said I have also found myself glue to this game for hours at a time. Don't let my playtime fool you much of my expeirence with this game is offline play, which steam fails to track. This game also seems to be in endless early access and constatly evolving, which helps to keep it feeling new and fresh.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not worth it yet. When I purchased it on release it was just a repackaged AaaaaAAaaaAAAaaAAAAaAAAAA!!! but song generated. It was fun but nothing special at all. Since then the game has changed a lot and isn't fun at all. But, recently an update came out saying the lack of news is due to the fact they hate how the game has turned out. Currently, they're gutting everything and restarting from almost from scratch. So, right now the game sucks but the good thing is the developers know it and are fixing it. Dejobaan is a great company that knows how to make a game. Check the reviews after release.

tl;dr
Not worth it yet but Dejobaan is a great company and is fixing what makes the game bad.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhen I first got this game, it was still in a state of moderate development. I enjoyed the orignial concept enough to sink a few hours into the game. I was curious when the most recent update came out, but was utterly disappointed. What was once a semi-enjoyable interactive music visualizer became a broken plot-based saga. The developers completely derailed the original concept of the game into an unenjoyable, uninspiring style of story mode" that leaves you wondering what the ♥♥♥♥ they were thinking. The game is now an unattractive mixture of bad level design
recommended: and absolutely horrendous music choice. After all that was promised when this title was orignially released
hoursPlayed: it is disheartening to see it go so quickly south."
voteText: October 9, 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There's something about this series that I find strangely relaxing; soaring through the sky, twirling around buildings ... similar to Mirror's Edge in feel, in that there is a genuine feeling of height and falling that is just oddly cathartic to me. I'd love to see this incorporated in another game; perhaps a way to make fast travel feel less like point and click and more like travelling fantastical distances (I've always felt like my character in Bethesda Games is doing a Megaman-esque beam up whenever I fast travel). This installment brings with it full mouse control, which I find to be very tight and easy to master, the ability to use your own tracks on some levels (Yes, I used Megalovania and Arachnophilia), and an interesting character in Asumi.

That said, this game has been in Early Access for quite a while, and I think I know why. As much as I like this, it does feel very much the same, and I think the developers know that and are trying to find new ways to mix up the formula. Now, I for one don't mind more of the same; I've already run through all the levels on the other games and like the idea of using my own music to mix things up again (Hopes and Dreams, people). If I had to throw in a criticism, though, the levels where I could use my own music didn't have as much level variety as I would've liked. I also echo the same sentiment as many; a free-fall option where you aren't stopped after three hits would be nice.

So do I recommend this?  I'm gonna go with a very tenative yes, with a suggestion that you pick up one of the others first if you're a prospective new player and wait and see if the project has truly been abandoned before putting more than a dollar of your money up for this title in particular. I sincerely hope this isn't the case; with VR already descending on the video game industry, this (along with the previous games) is one of the titles that makes me want to plunk down the cash to see where Asumi's story takes her.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's taken over 2 years, but this game is finally turning into something that's worth your money and has a great Dejobaan feel to it.

It's turned into a more casual version of AaaAAaa!!! If you liked AaaAAaa!!! and you like music games, it's definitely worth checking out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Did you like AAAAARRRRGGGGGGGHHHHHhhhhhhhh..... ... ?

If so you will love 1... 2... 3... .

Its much the same gameplay, though with tighter controls and can be played one-handed. Which is fantastic for one-handed gamers (A rather overlooked market frankly.)

The big difference between this and the previous base jumping entries from Dejobaaaaaaaaaaaan however is that you can (now, not in the future, you can do it now.) use your own Mp3 tracks to generate levels.

This is still early access however, so don't expect things to be perfect and realise there is no guarantee of a final polished product. But 1... 2... 3.. for the game it is NOW not the game you may get later.
